title: 113_s468
content: The Act may be cited as the "Coal Accountability and Retired Employee Act of 2013" or the "CARE Act." It amends the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977. Section 402(i)(2) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to transfer excess amounts to the trustees of the 1974 UMWA Pension Plan for pension benefits. The 1974 UMWA Pension Plan receives excess amounts for pension benefits as per Section 402(i)(2) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977. SEC. 3. ELIGIBILITY FOR 1992 UMWA BENEFIT PLAN. The amendment to section 9712(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows individuals who would be eligible for benefits from the 1974 UMWA Benefit Plan but do not receive sufficient coverage following insolvency proceedings to qualify for benefits. Amendment to section 9712(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 expands health benefits coverage eligibility under certain circumstances. SEC. 4. SPECIAL RULE FOR CERTAIN SUPPLEMENTAL BENEFIT PLANS. The new subsection (p) of Section 404 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a special rule for certain supplemental benefit plans. Contributions made by an employer under a plan providing supplemental benefits solely to participants in a pension plan will not be deductible under this section but will be governed by section 162. The trust holding the assets of such a plan will be treated as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(a). The new subsection (p) of Section 404 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a special rule for certain supplemental benefit plans. Contributions made by an employer under a plan providing supplemental benefits solely to participants in a pension plan will not be deductible under this section but will be governed by section 162. Payments made by an employer to the trustees of a plan and benefits paid by the trustees shall be treated as contributions paid to and benefits paid from the plan without regard to whether the contributions are paid into the trust holding the assets of the plan. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a special rule for certain supplemental benefit plans under section 404(p)(1). This includes collection of income tax at source and unemployment taxes related to payments made under such plans.
